articles.headline: States Help Ex-Inmates Find Jobs
articles.snippet: Advocates say it’s cheaper to try to prevent ex-convicts from resorting to crime than to lock up repeat offenders.
articles.abstract: Advocates say it’s cheaper to try to prevent ex-convicts from resorting to crime than to lock up repeat offenders.
articles.lead_paragraph: Faced with yawning budget gaps and high unemployment, California, Michigan, New York and several other states are attacking both problems with a surprising strategy: helping ex-convicts find jobs to keep them from ending up back in prison.

articles.headline: Ruling Blocks Emanuel’s Bid in Chicago Run
articles.snippet: After an appeals court ruling on Rahm Emanuel’s residency, the Illinois Supreme Court may be left to decide if he can run.
articles.abstract: After an appeals court ruling on Rahm Emanuel’s residency, the Illinois Supreme Court may be left to decide if he can run.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  With only a month to go until Election Day, more than $10 million in campaign money and an overwhelming lead in the polls, Rahm Emanuel, the former White House chief of staff, was disqualified on Monday from appearing on this city’s ballot for mayor.

articles.headline: Hezbollah Chooses Lebanon’s Next Prime Minister
articles.snippet: A victory for the Shiite movement has realigned Lebanon’s combustible politics and set off angry protests.
articles.abstract: A victory for the Shiite movement has realigned Lebanon’s combustible politics and set off angry protests.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A prime minister chosen by Hezbollah and its allies won enough support on Monday to form Lebanon’s government, unleashing angry protests, realigning politics and culminating the generation-long ascent of the Shiite Muslim movement from shadowy militant group to the country’s pre-eminent political and military force.

articles.headline: By Nature, Airports Have Risks
articles.snippet: Because airports are public places requiring relatively free access, security is a matter of improving safety, not ensuring it.
articles.abstract: Because airports are public places requiring relatively free access, security is a matter of improving safety, not ensuring it.
articles.lead_paragraph: How do you fully secure something as big and sprawling as an international airport against a terrorist bombing like the one on Monday at Domodedovo Airport in Moscow?

articles.headline: Uncertainty Over Economy Clouds Obama Speech
articles.snippet: As President Obama prepares to tackle the economy in his State of the Union address Tuesday, economists and industry executives are sifting through the data.
articles.abstract: As President Obama prepares to tackle the economy in his State of the Union address Tuesday, economists and industry executives are sifting through the data.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year ago, the economy looked as if it were speeding down the runway, only to stall out in the spring.

articles.headline: Food Makers Devise Own Label Plan
articles.snippet: The food industry said it created a plan at the urging of Michelle Obama, but she gave it only tepid approval.
articles.abstract: The food industry said it created a plan at the urging of Michelle Obama, but she gave it only tepid approval.
articles.lead_paragraph: Starting in the next few months, the front of many food packages will prominently display important nutrition information, including calorie, fat and sugar content. The industrywide program was announced Monday by food makers and grocers.

articles.headline: Alternative Fuels Don’t Benefit the Military, a RAND Report Says
articles.snippet: The report contends that the military is spending too much time and money exploring experimental biofuels.
articles.abstract: The report contends that the military is spending too much time and money exploring experimental biofuels.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States would derive no meaningful military benefit from increased use of alternative fuels to power its jets, ships and other weapons systems, according to a government-commissioned study by the RAND Corporation scheduled for release Tuesday.

articles.headline: Violent Clashes Mark Protests Against Mubarak’s Rule
articles.snippet: Thousands of Egyptians called for an end to the rule of President Hosni Mubarak. Nationwide, three people were reported killed.
articles.abstract: Thousands of Egyptians called for an end to the rule of President Hosni Mubarak. Nationwide, three people were reported killed.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  Tens of thousands of people demanding an end to the nearly 30-year rule of President Hosni Mubarak filled the streets of several Egyptian cities on Tuesday, in an unusually large and sometimes violent burst of civil unrest that appeared to threaten the stability of one of the United States’ closest Arab allies.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim and Mona El-Naggar

articles.headline: U.S. Home Prices Slump Again, Hitting New Lows
articles.snippet: The predicted double-dip in housing has begun, and analysts say declines are likely to continue, though not as intensely as in 2007 and 2008.
articles.abstract: The predicted double-dip in housing has begun, and analysts say declines are likely to continue, though not as intensely as in 2007 and 2008.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new slide in housing prices has begun in earnest, with averages in major cities across the country falling to their lowest point in many years.
